content.content: MIP89: Monetalis - Arrow Andalusian  Preamble MIP#: 89 Title: Monetalis - Arrow Andalusian Author(s): @Allan_Pedersen , @Wrongcomma Contributors:  Type: General Status: Withdrawn Date Proposed: 2022-10-12 Date Ratified:  Dependencies: MIP21 Replaces: None Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip89-monetalis-arrow-andalusian/18338  Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmdPooRY#vote-breakdown   References  MIP65: Monetalis Clydesdale MIP82: Monetalis/Coinbase Appaloosa MIP88: Monetalis/Redwood Friesian Arrow Global   Sentence Summary MIP89 will onboard and activate a DAI 300M RWA vault and acquire BlackRock/ishares ETF products allocated in the same manner as MIP65, and, from this asset pool, finance and deploy over 12 months a set of wholesale, senior, secure, staged, Green Economy, Lending facility focused on the UK and the EU together with Arrow Global.  Paragraph Summary MIP89 will onboard and activate a DAI 300M RWA vault and acquire BlackRock/ishares ETF products allocated in the same manner as MIP65, and, from this asset pool, finance and deploy over 12 months a set of wholesale, senior, secure, staged, Green Economy, Lending facility focused on the UK and the EU together with Arrow Global. The legal, structural, and technical setup will be “close cousins” of the structure and technical implementation under MIP65 and proposed under MIP82 and will be executed under a strict verification program.  Component Summary MIP89c1: Collateral Design This component contains the proposed loan/collateral counterparties, key terms and legal structure. MIP89c2: Verification Conditions for Collateral Onboarding This component sets out the verification mechanism and conditions ensuring appropriate collateral is onboarded using an appropriate legal structure and governance framework using an appropriate technical solution. MIP89c3: Technical Conditions of the Collateral Onboarding This component contains the technical requirements for unambiguous technical execution of the collateral onboarding  Motivation With this credit facility, Maker will gain on a number of fronts:  Operationalize the Clean Money vision in a scalable and credible manner together with an aligned credit counterpart with similar Clean Money/ESG aspirations Gain scalable exposure to the UK and the EU private credit markets Conduct this business together with a strong and well-established European credit player: Arrow Global Access private credit structure yields Diversification directly in the exposure (mixed credit portfolios) and indirectly against Maker allocations into US based assets and US Treasuries Well-protected Senior Credit exposure and aligned junior capital.   Specification / Proposal Details  774×517 789 KB  Andalusian AI’d by nightcafe  MIP89c1: Collateral Design  c1.1 Counterparty: Arrow Global  We here let Arrow present themselves in their own words: “…Arrow is an established, prominent leader and credit manager in the European market across the U.K., the Netherlands, Ireland, Italy and Portugal. It was originally founded in 2005 by Zach Lewy with SallieMae as a highly differentiated vertically integrated asset manager. Arrow has a rating of BB- from Fitch and B1 from Moody’s with two complementary business lines: Investing: Arrow Global has invested in excess of €7 billion over the last seventeen years across over a thousand deals in a broad range of European credit and real estate investment opportunities, achieving an 18% gross IRR with consistent performance and attractive diversification. Asset servicing: Vertically-integrated operational platform across the U.K., the Netherlands, Ireland, Italy and Portugal and certain other leading capital markets jurisdictions; manages approximately €70 billion (gross book value) covering approximately ten million accounts of borrowers and approximately 35 million data records, taking advantage of the Arrow Platform’s key European regulatory licences. It is the harmonious combination of local market expertise access and origination capability with credit investing know-how across a broad range of opportunities that underpins our vertically integrated model and our profile of results. Arrow Global’s growth and development reflect its commitment to bring to its capital investment activity in the credit sector not only its deep experience in sourcing, diligencing, pricing and executing with respect to investment transactions, but also its commitment to sophisticated portfolio servicing, including servicing related to bespoke management services in respect of NPLs, non-core banking assets, certain real estate related assets and other assets acquired out of distressed situations, with the attendant benefits of deep portfolio knowledge that supports its opportunistic, analytics-driven portfolio decision-making. Arrow Global has an extensive history of investing capital from its own balance sheet, as well as via co-investments with other leading credit investors, into high-value niche Arrow-originated assets and in 2019, Arrow’s first fund, Arrow Credit Opportunities I (“ACO I”), was launched to deliver this strategy to external investors. The final closing of ACO I took place in November 2020 with €1.7 billion of capital commitments, including the Arrow Global commitment, and ACO I was nominated by Preqin as one of the largest Europe-focused private debt funds closed and also one of the largest first-time credit funds raised globally in 2020. Arrow Global remains focused on enhancement and evolution of its ownership of portfolio servicing businesses as a world-class, Europe-focused network for sourcing and pricing investment opportunities in a range of attractive markets. The Arrow Platform provides bespoke management services in respect of European investment opportunities. The Arrow Platform represents an attractive channel for deal sourcing that benefits from a range of important relationships conducive to closing on acquisitions of loan portfolios and other credit investment opportunities on attractive terms with leading market participants. Arrow’s proprietary business model of owning and operating the leading “local” servicers within jurisdictions, which provides Arrow with an exclusive source of Off-Market opportunities, a local knowledge advantage and the ability to assess and select assets from a broad range of credit opportunities. For example, Arrow owns a significant minority of the leading lender in UK living spaces construction sector, Maslow Capital. Maslow operates to the highest of ESG standards, underwriting to UN Sustainable Development Goals. Arrow, via its large credit servicing business, has a clear direct management and data advantage that allows Arrow to work with smaller portfolios at scale which produce:a better diversified, higher yielding and more stable performance across credit cycles. For avoidance of doubt, when referring to Arrow, this means any fund, vehicle or investment portfolio established and controlled by Arrow or its affiliates or for which Arrow or its affiliates act as manager or exercise discretionary control over or enjoy economic benefit in respect of, in each case from time to time. Arrow Financial Summary:  Arrow Global has never had a year below a 10% gross IRR in its history, with a cumulative loss rate of sub 1.5%. Over 80% of the transactions consummated by Arrow were from repeat transaction sources; The current pipeline is trending towards higher volume with consistent returns and similar asset quality. Arrow Global has strong financial credentials and the consolidated results for 2021 show free cash flow of £182.1m, adjusted EBITDA of £260.8m and balance sheet collections of £367.4m.  Arrow continues to pursue integration with, and development of, DeFi projects. These initiatives currently include:  Creating a fully native blockchain financial instrument, which creates new opportunities on how cash flows in collections are rated and delivers efficiencies in recycling of cash Further warehousing opportunity with equity type yields that supports the seasoning of newly originated assets Distribution of such instruments through regulated markets Distribution of such instruments with Monetalis as a potentially higher yielding product than corporate bond programs  …” We, Monetalis, believe Arrow has all the hallmarks of a potential cornerstone partner for Maker in private credit for Europe. Following a potential approval of the 400m strategy here, Arrow and Monetalis  will aim to work together to deliver a full roadmap, outlining an ambitious and market changing long-term relationship that intends to bring real change to what are currently very static, rigid, archaic credit markets in Europe.  c1.2 ESG Alignment Arrow Global adheres to UN PRI principles and is building up reporting and management according to these requirements. As it today routinely onboards capital from some of the largest investors in the world, Arrow meets a common best practice standard already. Arrow has an ongoing continuous improvement program for implementation of ESG practices into its relevant portfolios. An example of Arrow’s approach to ESG, on a deal level, is how Arrow review each UK residential development loan on their Maslow Capital platform against the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which can be see here  c1.3 Structure Our starting point is the same structure as used with MIP65 and proposed for MIP82 - we add a further separate trust to the structure for this particular facility (“Felix Asset Trust”) as illustrated in green here:  940×623 151 KB  In addition, one or more SPV orphan entities (“Lux SPV”) will be set up in Luxembourg, which will act as the lender/buyer of the portfolio(s). The lending capital in Lux SPV will be provided by Arrow and Felix Asset Trust on a Junior(Arrow)/Senior(Felix Asset Trust) basis. This relationship is structured via an appropriate complex of market standard facility agreements to match with each individual portfolio situation, and fit within one of the two respective Master Facility Framework Agreements and their respective Credit Guidelines. The structure is designed to be a tax and operational cost optimised for conducting business with portfolios across the EU and the UK.  c1.4 Strategy We have split the overall vault facility into two strategies: 1. “Arrow Advantage” To take full advantage of Arrow’s credit market experience, we focus exclusively on non-bank lenders and facilities that Arrow are fully committed to - i.e.  Have positive, long-term credit history with Have credit administration history with Have equity (or equity-like) commitment to the lender Provides 15% Junior capital to Work with the lender on GHG emssions measurements and aligned with a Clean Money vision  This provides substantial security and comfort around Makers senior, secured facility position. We expect, for diversification purposes, to deploy across approximately 3 to 5 portfolios. 2. “Boost” To take advantage of the well-established Senior, Secured, Block Discount market in the UK and the fact that this market has shorter maturities than we’d expect to see in strategy 1, and reasonable yields, we have chosen to include a smaller strategy that has quicker cashflow. This provides a better overall diversification, cashflow profile and risk character of the total portfolio that comprises both strategies.  c.1.5 “Arrow Advantage” / Key Terms  c.1.5.1 Master Facility Framework “Arrow Advantage”     Component Key Terms     Parties  James Asset PTC Limited, BVI (Trustee) for Felix  Asset Trust (Trust) Arrow Global Monetalis    Amount 250M   Use of funding Wholesale Senior, Secured Lending in UK//EU Markets   Deployment Full deployment over 12 months   Collateral Hard Assets & Properties Examples of collateral would include:Granular UK residential development and completed homes Irish energy efficient homes (refurbished from old, inefficient housing stock) Dutch green office buildings and facilities Large scale solar installations Social housing projects across UK and Europe EV charging stations and battery storage Electric vehicle purchasing contracts    Lenders “Arrow Advantage” Lenders only as defined under strategy c.1.4   Junior Capital 15% provided by Arrow across facilities   Clean Money GHG measurement requirements on all lenders (or similar relevant green credential reporting required depending upon the specific asset)   Diversification 3 to 5 portfolios   Term Max weighted average duration of underlying loans on outstanding portfolio: 24 months   Currency Lending in GBP/EUR but hedged to USD   Waterfall 1. 3.5% in USD to James Asset Trust on Senior2. 15% to Arrow on Junior 3. Profit-share of 40% to James Asset Trust/60% to Arrow All net of currency hedging and all other cost   Capital recycling Principal payments are recirculated back into their relevant strategy until withdrawal request from Maker. Interest payments - after expenses - are also recirculated until requested paid into Surplus Buffer.     c.1.5.1 Credit Guidelines “Arrow Advantage” All facilities will need to meet the minimum credit guidelines set out in the table below.     Component Key criteria     Facility type Senior secured only   Equity/Junior capital Arrow Global to provide 15% Junior position across all facilities   Security type * Properties  * Property development  * Infrastructures  * Hard assets + Receivables   Security value Independently valued   Loss of capital Less than 2% over the last five years, or since inception.   Cross guarantees Cross guarantee between strategies   Eligible facility types * Revolving Credit facilities  * Loan on loan  * Block discounts   Existing portfolios 30% or less of the portfolio over 50% maturity   Loan types All loans must be ESG eligible and aligned to Monetalis’ Green Strategy   Underlying loan terms Max weighted average duration of underlying loans on outstanding portfolio across all facilities: 28 months   Collateralisation * Min collateralization on the facility 120% * Min collateralization on security: 145%   Min. facility term 12 months   Geographic Diversification * UK and EU only  * Less than 50% per country     c1.6 “Boost” / Key Terms  c1.6.1 Master Facility Framework “Boost”     Component Key Terms     Parties  James Asset PTC Limited, BVI (Trustee) for Felix  Asset Trust (Trust) Monetalis Arrow Global    Amount 50M   Use of funding Senior, Secured, Block Purchase UK Market   Deployment Full deployment over 6 months   Currency GBP fully-hedged against USD   Target returns to James Asset Trust 5%+ net   Senior Block Waterfall 1. 3.5% in USD to James Asset Trust  2. 1% to Monetalis  3, Profit-share 55% James Asset Trust/35% Monetalis/10% Arrow   Collateral  Properties Infrastructures Hard assets + Receivables    Capital recycling Principal payments are recirculated back into their relevant strategy until withdrawal request from Maker. Interest payments - after expenses - are also recirculated until requested paid into Surplus Buffer.     c1.6.2 Credit Guidelines “Boost” All blocks purchased under the “Booster Block Purchase” facility will need to meet the minimum credit guidelines set out in the table below.     Component Key criteria     Facility type Senior secured only   Equity The originator will need to demonstrate a robust equity position   Security type Property or Hard Assets   Security value Independently valued   Loss of capital Less than 1% over the the last five years   First loss capital Blocks are purchased at a discounted rate of 85% or less of the outstanding block value.   Concentration risk Less than 1% on single unit developed / funded   Cross guarantees Cross guarantee within the strategy   Underlying loan terms Max weighted average duration of underlying loans on outstanding portfolio: 24 months   Collateralisation  Min collateralization on the block 125% Min collateralization on security: 145%    Min. Block term 6 months   Geographic Diversification UK Only:80% England and Wales 20% Scotland and Northern Ireland      c1.7 Key Credit Facility Governance All proposed facilities will need to be validated and approved to ensure they comply with the Master Facility and Credit Guidelines. The process will following these steps:  Opportunity is identified and all associated documents submitted to Monetalis. Monetalis assess that the opportunity aligns to agreed Framework Credit Guidelines and that it delivers the best possible returns. Monetalis approves facility External legal counsel to verify and validate that the proposed facility aligns to the credit guidelines. The panel of external legal counsels will be  Addleshaw Goddard DLA Piper.   Facility approved for disbursal.   c1.8 Liquidity Considerations & Market Changes In the short term, these portfolios will not be liquid assets. Although there are active participants that are willing to buy or refinance these portfolios, these are not fast processes, and shouldn’t be relied upon for quick liquidity. However, this vault is meant to be the start of a longer term strategy of Arrow, Monetalis and Maker - we would suggest - to recreate the private credit market using DeFi/CeFi/TradFi integration to create liquidity in the products. Significant resource across the Arrow and Monetalis teams are allocated to this project of integration and building markets to facilitate a new state of liquidity for private credit structures.  c1.9 Asset Class Comparison & Yield Expectations     Strategy Base Rate Est Ultimate Yield to Maker     US Treasuries 3.50% 3.50%   US CMBS 5.50% 5.50%   UK Gilts 4.00% 4.00%   Arrow UK Resi 3.50% 5.50%   Arrow UK Resi Dev 3.50% 7.00%   Arrow Irish Resi 3.50% 8.50%   Arrow UK EV Credit 3.50% 8.75%     c1.10 Examples of Arrow’s Underlying portfolios Underlying asset classes will range depending on markets, but in all instances will provide strong downside protection. For example:   Irish residential units in Dublin, purchased for EUR 250k, with EUR 50k capital expenditure to significantly improve energy efficiency. Many of these units would have been built decades ago, and will therefore be incredibly energy inefficient. The units will be completely stripped back to their base shell, and refurbished to a very high standard, increasing energy rating by at least 2 levels. In addition, approximately 20% of the units will be taken from existing stock that has not been lived in for 2+ years, bringing isolated housing stock back into use in a local market that has a real undersupply issue, helping to solve for material social detriment.   UK residential housing developments, built in £10m+ projects. Each project must maintain to Arrow’s local green sustainable scorecard, monitoring items such as:  Embodied and operational carbon, to RIBA standards. Minimum waste diversion from landfills Minimum thermal standards for floors, walls, roofs, and air permeability    Credit agreements to UK Uber drivers to purchase electric vehicles. Working with an existing lender who is on Uber’s current panel of promoted lenders to drivers, we can provide capital to help convert Uber’s London fleet from ICE to EV. Uber has committed to having all of their London fleet electric by end of 2025, and Transport for London currently will only allow newly licensed vehicles to be electric.    c1.11 Currency Hedging At this time we’re still assessing market options for currency hedging, but based on our conversations with a prominent investment bank, our intention would be to enter into cross currency swaps where:   For GBP floating rate assets, you enter a swap where the SPV pays GBP daily compounded SONIA + spread, and receives USD daily compounded SOFR + spread   For EUR floating rate assets, you enter a swap where the SPV pays EURIBOR + spread and receives USD daily compounded SOFR + spread   This would remove much of the FX risk between USD and GBP/EUR, and also allow for protection should we enter into any floating rate facilities. We expect the majority of our positions to be fixed, and therefore we may well be able to simplify this further. From an operational perspective, we would enter into the hedges on day 1 of any FX exposure, then each month top up based on the updated exposure and expected run off. If the pool ramps as expected, we would have 24 swaps over 2 years. To clean this up at the end of the ramp period, we can restructure these all into just one swap with a weighted average spread over SOFR and FX rate. Ultimately we will be able to pass a lot of the heavy lifting and execution of this strategy to a 3rd party, and the overall hedging we’re looking to put in place is relatively simple.  MIP89c2: Verification Conditions for Collateral Onboarding  c2.1 Legal Structure and Governance Verification Requirements At least one community member, with legal credentials, must, through a public forum post, validated by at least one Facilitator, provide a verification of the legal and governance structure appropriateness for holding a large amount of low-risk real-world asset collateral for Maker.  c2.2 Lending Arrangement Key Terms Verification Requirements The Strategic Finance Core Unit Facilitator must, through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the Lending Agreements Business Terms & Risks ensuring the appropriateness of this USDC allocation for Maker and its ALM strategy.  c2.3 Technical Verification Requirements The Collateral Engineering Services Facilitator must, through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the technical appropriateness of the MIP21 designed solution in accordance with the Collateral Onboarding process (“COB”). Should any one of the above verifications not be forthcoming, for whatever reason, this MIP will not move forward in the COB.  MIP89c3: Technical Conditions of the Collateral Onboarding The technical implementation must follow the MIP21 framework. Upon Collateral Engineering Services solution Verification in MIP89c2, the relevant smart contracts must be constructed and deployed. The ETH Address emitted by the legal structure specified in MIP89c1 should only be changeable by MakerDAO Governance, and follow the MIP21 framework. These smart contracts must only allow for the generation of Dai or USDC through a vault that is sent to the ETH address of the legal structure as its ultimate destination, and it must not be technically possible to send the Dai or USDC elsewhere, in accordance with MIP21. There must also not be any additional technical features or complexity that goes beyond the minimum necessary smart contracts and dummy constructs to enable the generation of Dai and its transfer to the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure. The ability to initiate the generation of Dai or USDC from the vault and trigger their transfer to the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure is given to an Ethereum address controlled by Monetalis. This address must have no ability to access the funds. When the collateral onboarding process for MIP89 has progressed to step 7 in the COB, an executive vote must be created (or code must be bundled into a broader executive vote) that activates all permissions for the vault to be onboarded based on the smart contracts specified in MIP89c3. The vault must provide:  Debt Ceiling of DAI 300 million. Stability Fee of 0% (surplus is paid manually through the legal structure, as specified in MIP89c1) All other parameters must be set to ensure they have no functional impact.

This is a summary of the contents of this proposal and its impact, from GovAlpha’s perspective:  This is a valid proposal, eligible to enter the November Governance Cycle. This MIP aims to onboard and activate a DAI 300M RWA vault, acquire BlackRock/ishares ETF products, and finance and deploy a set of lending facility focused on the UK and the EU over a 12-month period in collaboration with Arrow Global. The precise technical specification is not listed. As MIP65 and proposed for MIP82, collateral is held off-chain by a third party in a separate trust which in this proposal will act as lender/buyer of the different properties and hard assets portfolios. The operation proposed is structured through market-standard private credit line agreements to suit each individual portfolio situation, with a minimum collaterization ratio on the block of 125%, a minimum collateralization on security of 145%, and with up to an estimate yield for Maker of 8.5%. The proposal clarifies that in the short term, these portfolios will not be liquid assets. Legal work is required to verify the legality and appropriatness for holding collateral in this structure. This proposal requires technical work based on the structure of MIP21 to develop smart contracts with appropriate permissions and security to enable this lending structure. If this MIP is ratified a final poll will be submitted prior to inclusion of the lending structure and vault permissions in an executive proposal. This will include the results of legal and technical assessments and a final stability fee agreement. This proposal has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here. This proposal is eligible to the November Governance Cycle.  Disclaimer: These summaries are intended to be a guide and not a source of truth. You remain responsible for any actions you take on the grounds of this information. Please note the date when the summary was last updated to judge Last edit: 2022-11-13

Hi @flipflopflapdelegate Thank you for the questions!     flipflopflapdelegate:  Can you please clarify is the requested Vault will be used for a new Fund, or one of Arrow’s previous funds?   Arrow will provide junior capital to “mix” with senior capital from this Vault from either their new (ACO 2) or old fund (ACO 1) depending upon the credit opportunity. It doesn’t matter much from the Maker/Monetalis point of view - both funds are run by the same people and have the same risk/return & scope mandate.     flipflopflapdelegate:  And is the requested 300M DAI diversified within Arrow, or Monetalis looks to place a portion of the 300M DAI with Arrow, and the remaining balances in different scopes?   250M of the Vault will act as Senior, Secured lending capital with Arrow providing 15% Junior Capital (i.e. ~45M) on the lending facility (i.e. loan facilities worth 250M+~45M = ~295M will be funded). And, importantly, this is junior capital across the facilities. Arrow has a rather exceptional track-record so we feel quite comfortable with the portfolio that we build up together with them with their junior capital “in front” on Maker capital.  image1052×543 186 KB  However, these “Arrow cooperation” lending facilities are longer term in nature and doesn’t quickly recycle capital or are quickly liquid, so in this proposal we added a 50M that would be put into buying what is called Block purchases - i.e. you buy into existing credit portfolios that has quick cash flow conversion and short remaining term to them - and reasonable interest rates and importantly are highly collateralized.The provision of junior capital  for these blocks will vary depending on the product and company we are funding. In some instances, the company already has a junior provision or enough equity to cover the junior part of the funding. In other cases, where the opportunity is suitable and the company requires junior capital, Arrow will aim to provide the necessary junior capital. We also, work with Arrow on the review of each of these Blocks and Arrow appointees sit on the credit committee for these purchases to ensure consistency in credit decisions quality. This combo - in sum - provides a better mix of cash flow from this vault to Maker in our view - and Maker gains materially from the credit relationship with Arrow.     flipflopflapdelegate:  You know when you look at the Fossil CO2 Top Emitting Countries, Germany is by far the largest emitting country in Europe. I don’t believe Arrow has much exposure to central Europe–is their GHG initiative mostly focus in the UK, and how does Arrow plan to expand beyond western Europe?    image820×617 160 KB  As can be seen in this map, Arrow is active in the UK, Ireland, Portugal, Italy, and the Netherlands - and the GHG emission initiative certainly goes across all these country activities. At the time of writing, Arrow has no plans to expand into Germany, however as with any growing company, they are always looking at new opportunities.     flipflopflapdelegate:  In your opinion, how do you believe MakerDAO can position itself as an influential participant of perhaps future United Nations Climate Change Conferences, such as COP29 and beyond?   I would hope so. Maker may not be the largest climate change investor in the world, but it can somewhat help “lead the way” in many aspects by allocating capital to key solutions that not just meet Maker risk/return requirements but shows how certain climate finance challenges can be solved. Some of this is outlined in the Viridian Cluster post, but, for instance, we know that not enough climate change assets are being built fast enough to satisfy neither demand nor climate change needs. We also know that a key problem is connecting short-term investors with long-term financing of climate assets. So, with Arrow here, we are trying to address both of these problems:  we are building up portfolio’s of climate change assets - and; we are developing an asset tokenization solution (this is not in this MIP - still working it through - not as easy as one might think) that will allow us to list on token markets the Maker positions built with Arrow (i.e. bridging short-term investors with long-term financing).  So that is one avenue for where Maker can gain a strong voice in a global forum. Another string to pull is the fact that a lot of the measurements in the GHG measurement space rely on blockchain solutions - and so - there should be some valuable solutions coming up where these measurement solutions are directly integrated into CeFi/DeFi automated products. So - all in all - I am very optimistic about Maker punching well above its weight in climate finance and building a voice in places like UN programs etc.     flipflopflapdelegate:  Can you please provide any social sustainability programs that Arrow has provided recently, such as charitable and volunteering programs?   As a company of approximately 2,500 people across Europe, Arrow has a wide range of charitable and volunteering programmes taking place. One example took place in the first half of 2022 where Arrow teamed up with Junior Achievement Europe to deliver financial education across 4 countries. These activities have seen over 60 volunteers from Arrow working with 2,208 students in Albania, Ireland, Italy, and Portugal.  Albania: there were 7 Finance Boot Camps and Career Days in Tirana and Cerrik Ireland: working with 100 students from CBS Westland Row in Dublin Italy: held a master class on business planning, holding a national Company Programme competition Portugal: Job Shadow day, Company Programme competition, Economics for Success workshop      flipflopflapdelegate:  EDIT: Do you have any examples of the generate revenues by Arrow from managing and servicing assets on behalf of other third parties?   As at 2021 HY, Arrow’s 3rd party fee income from their AMS and FIM businesses was £55.6m. All of Arrow’s public financial information can be found here

Monetalis is mainly acting something akin (but not entirely alike) a fund-of-fund and so our fees are being structured to work generally as such. But this is still in the works. The Arranger role is a lot more intensive than a fund-of-fund in initial structuring, day-to-day operations and communication, etc, but on the other hand it is not the role of the ultimate investor etc etc - so still figuring out what is fair and reasonable. We will make sure to update the MIP as we figure this out clearly.

Allan Pedersen has asked if I would respond to your question directly on the forum, but before I do I would like to thank the MakerDAO for allowing me to speak at the G&R session a few days ago and to represent Arrow in the discussion with the forum.    Fletchings    Fletchings, Guided by Arrow. Providing insight and intelligence to investors who want to gain a better understanding of the opportunities inherent in the European credit market.      To answer your questions:    Creating a fully native blockchain financial instrument, which creates new opportunities on how cash flows in collections are rated and delivers efficiencies in recycling of cash.    Answer: Myself and a team of people from across the Arrow business, have been working on a new approach to predict the collection of cashflow from loan portfolios, we then overlay the new prediction model with the tokenisation of real world assets (loan portfolios and cash), to create financial products that could not otherwise have been made with traditional methods or if they could they would be uneconomical to manage due to their complexity. Using blockchain we’ve been able to tokenise the monthly expected receipt of cash, decoupling it from the underlying asset, then we use DataSci to run a series of 75-100,000 MonteCarlo simulations against a number macro and micro economic assumptions to calculate the probability of each block of cash,  we then reconnect the tokenised probability with the real world asset, to create a fully portable Tokenised Digital Asset that can be “stacked” in any sequence, this gives us the tools to build any financial instrument, with any characteristic, based on the market’s or buyer’s needs. Now the models are complete, we’re working with the ratings agencies to backtest and benchmark our methods against the legacy models for ratings, we expect to see a material pricing advantage with our new model. In the early stages, Arrow hopes to use these new tools to create liquidity in the illiquid asset classes we own, then as the tools and the markets mature, we hope to democratise access to fixed income investments (investment bonds). We see an opportunity to create yield enhanced fixed income investments, that carry full data and performance provenance with the Digital Asset, something that has historically only been available to institutional investors and very large scale. Our project is well advanced, with a first issuance aimed in early 2023. Q2: * Further warehousing opportunity with equity type yields that supports the seasoning of newly originated assets Answer: We’ve had early discussion with Monetalis regarding what it would look like to take a programatic approach to buying portfolios of loans, essentially “to order” (these could be ESG targeted portfolios ) with the “Day 1” intention of digitising the cashflows and assets and to create and sell the fixed income investments mentioned in the previous response, ie done as a long term program, scaling up over a number of years vs one off spot transactions. Our 17years in loan servicing and cashflow collections, tells us that we need 12-18mths of collections data for the probability models to deliver the accuracy needs to create the bonds in a program format. Investing in and buying asset portfolios is what Arrow does as a core business, with around 7bn Euro of our own money invested. This investment model is how Arrow makes  the 18% returns on equity that it does. We also service around 70bn Euro for around 200 banks and financial institutions, across 5 countries in Europe. The proposal to Monetalis was for Monetalis to act as one of our Limited Partner (LP) investors, but only to cover the first 18mths of the portfolio ownership, after which Arrow would buy the portfolios back from Monetalis on a forward flow agreement, where Arrow would then take the portfolios and the servicing data in order to  build tokenised Fixed Income Investments, to be sold to the wider market.  The upside for Monetalis would be that while it holds the portfolios, Monetalis would receive the equity level returns from those portfolios, but with guaranteed asset sale at the end of 18mths.  That way Arrow and Monetalis could collectively build a uniquely scaleable fixed income financial services business, back by the funding capacity of the MakerDAO. Q3: * Distribution of such instruments through regulated markets Answer: Out of the discussions we had with Allan and Alessio some months ago, Allan and Alessio introduced us to the team at Oasis Pro Markets in the US. The intention was that Oasis might be a possible distribution channel for Arrow’s first Digital Asset transaction and a venue/liquidity provider for the ongoing Fixed Income program.  We are currently working through some of the US regulatory requirements with the team at Oasis and are optimistic about relationship. Q4: * Distribution of such instruments with Monetalis as a potentially higher yielding product than corporate bond programs Answer: The objective of the Arrow tokenised Digital Asset program is to build a sophisticated, yet transparent, yield enhanced, Fixed Income Bonds program. We see an opportunity to work with Monetalis to design a series of bespoke higher yielding bonds  that may be of interest to the Maker community or DAI holders, as we (Arrow) are already working to design a number of products styles, based on the 12-13 different asset classes that Arrow currently owns, as each asset class has it’s own unique profile of collateral, cashflow and risk. We truly think the Arrow/Monetalis/MakerDAO intersection of TradFi and DeFi is potentially very exciting. Hope this gives the forum some additional colour on what we are working on at Arrow. If interested we have an investor site with some published data highlights for the Arrow business. https://www.arrowfletchings.net/ Thanks and regards John Pellew Group Head of IT and Principal Distribution & Securitisation

Hi @fumoffuXx Please see below for answers:     fumoffuXx:  Q1: what is the default rate of the loans in your historical and current portfolio combined?   The senior, secured loan positions that Maker are provided have not had any historical ultimate losses. This, btw, is in line with the credit guideline requirements presented above - and has been verified through a due diligence of the portfolios.     fumoffuXx:  Q2: what would be done should a borrower decides to repay its debt should he find out the loan has changed hands?   It so very rarely happens, but if they did then it would be wonderful as it increases yield (from early repayment fees etc) and accelerates cash-flow. We have more than enough credit pipeline for capital recycling of such accelerated repayment cash flows.     fumoffuXx:  Q3: how strigent is your collection teams in the recovery of interest andwhat would be done when any payment lapses?   This very much depends on the asset class, but it is our intention to recover fees, interest, and principal in all instances. Where the loan is secured, like the proposed program here, our lending is done in such a way that there is sufficient credit buffer, well in excess of the amount lent, to enforce the loan and recover all interest, fees, and principal from the ultimate sale of the assets. In reality, Arrow have built up significant experience in handling loans if they default, and have a wide variety of routes to ultimate recovery. All portfolios funded are not just assessed in terms of historic default rates but also in terms of Loss Given Default, i.e. the ability of the lender to recover outstanding principal and interest balances in the event of default. This analysis also helps set very comfortable Collaterisation ratios that ensure the necessary protection for Maker senior funding facilities.     fumoffuXx:  Q4: are all loans purchase securtised? and is the underlying asset worth more than the loans?   On the first part of your question: this will depend on the county and asset class. Some jurisdictions lend themselves - or even require - securitisation, where others make it easier to remain in simple loan format. Equally, if the original loan isn’t securitised, we may need to securitise through the general structures to be able to pass capital to and from all of the parties involved. On the second part of your question the answer is a crystal clear Yes! Under this proposal Maker will provide senior facilities of up to 85% of the loan funded, so it will immediately have a coverage ratio of  circa 120% against the loan receivables and of anything between 140% and 160% - or even more - on the underlying security.     fumoffuXx:  Q5: any other management fees or performances fees subjected to MAKER?   No - all fees are otherwise within the structure’s waterfall payments etc

NOTA: Se entregarán más detalles antes de que finalice el RFC   MIP89c2: Condiciones de Verificación para la Incorporación de Colateral  NOTA: Esta sección puede ser editada durante el periodo del RFC para ajustarse a las consecuencias del Endgame.   c2.1 Estructura jurídica y requisitos de verificación de la gobernanza Al menos un miembro de la comunidad, con credenciales legales, debe, a través de un mensaje en un foro público, validado por al menos un Facilitador, proporcionar una verificación de la idoneidad de la estructura legal y de gobernanza para mantener una gran cantidad de activos de bajo riesgo en el mundo real como colateral para Maker.  c2.2 Acuerdo de préstamo Términos clave Requisitos de verificación El Facilitador de la Core Unit de Financiación Estratégica debe, a través de un mensaje en el foro público, proporcionar una Verificación de los Términos y Riesgos de los Acuerdos de Préstamo que garantice la idoneidad de esta asignación de USDC para Maker y su estrategia de ALM.  c2.3 Requisitos de verificación técnica El Facilitador de Servicios de Ingeniería de Colateral debe, a través de un mensaje en el foro público, proporcionar una Verificación de la idoneidad técnica de la solución diseñada por el MIP21 de acuerdo con el proceso de Incorporación de Colaterales (“COB”). En caso de que alguna de las verificaciones anteriores no se produzca, por el motivo que sea, este MIP no avanzará en el COB.  MIP89c3: Condiciones técnicas de la Incorporación de Colaterales  NOTA: Esta sección puede ser editada durante el periodo del RFC para ajustarse a las consecuencias de Endgame.  La implementación técnica debe seguir el marco MIP21. Tras la verificación de la solución de los Servicios de Ingeniería Colateral en MIP89c2, los contratos inteligentes pertinentes deben ser construidos y desplegados. La dirección ETH emitida por la estructura legal especificada en MIP89c1 sólo debe ser modificable por la Gobernanza de MakerDAO, y seguir el marco MIP21. Estos contratos inteligentes sólo deben permitir la generación de Dai o USDC a través de una vault que se envía a la dirección de ETH de la estructura legal como su destino final, y no debe ser técnicamente posible enviar el Dai o USDC a otro lugar, de acuerdo con MIP21. Tampoco debe haber ninguna característica o complejidad técnica adicional que vaya más allá de los contratos inteligentes y construcciones ficticias mínimas necesarias para permitir la generación de Dai y su transferencia a la dirección de ETH emitida por la estructura legal. La capacidad de iniciar la generación de Dai o USDC desde la vault y desencadenar su transferencia a la Dirección de ETH emitida por la estructura legal se otorga a una dirección de Ethereum controlada por Monetalis. Esta dirección no debe tener capacidad de acceso a los fondos. Cuando el proceso de incorporacion de el colateral para el MIP89 ha avanzado hasta el paso 7 en el COB, se debe crear un voto ejecutivo (o el código se debe agrupar en un voto ejecutivo más amplio) que active todos los permisos para la incorporacion de la vault basado en los contratos inteligentes especificados en el MIP89c3. La vault debe proporcionar:  Techo de Deuda de DAI 300 millones. Tasa de estabilidad del 0% (el excedente se paga manualmente a través de la estructura jurídica, como se especifica en el MIP89c1) Todos los demás parámetros deben ajustarse para que no tengan ningún impacto funcional.
